candidates.title: New Federal Gun Law Prevents Open Carry in All 50 States
candidates.content:
Claim:
A federal gun law was passed in September 2016 which will prevent people from practicing "open carry" in all 50 states.
On 16 September 2016, the disreputable web site Associated Media Coverage published an article reporting that the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives had announced the implementation of a new gun law that would prevent "open carry" in all 50 states:
Representatives from the ATF (Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives) have announced the implementation of a new federal gun law preventing the practice of open carry in all 50-states.
The term open carry refers to the practice of openly carrying a firearm in public which differs from concealed carry, where firearms cannot be seen by the casual observer.
According to Carl Peterson, a spokesperson for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the regulation was implemented in effort to create uniformity among states and increase public safety.
While Associated Media Coverage provided several links in their article, giving it an appearance of credibility, none of those links directed readers to sources containing additional information about this purported new law.
The article also claimed that that the ATF had worked with the Brady Campaign, Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, EveryTown for Gun Safety, and Moms Demand Action in implementing this alleged law, yet none of those groups has made any announcements regarding it. (Not to mention that the ATF is tasked with enforcing laws, not making them; the latter privilege still rests with the federal legislative body known as Congress.)
Associated Media Coverage is a well-known purveyor of fake news, a site that has previously published false stories concerning a motorcycle curfew and a ban on religious content on Facebook. Although many readers may now be familiar with Associated Media Coverage's reputation, the site has recently started publishing articles under the banner for a fictitious newspaper called "The Boston Tribune":
While Associated Media Coverage may be changing their name to The Boston Tribune, their content is still nothing more than fake news.
candidates.description: A fake news article reported that the ATF is implementing a new law banning the practice of "open carry" throughout the U.S.

result.explanation: The provided text explicitly states that the claim in the news caption is false.  Source 1, from Snopes, directly debunks the claim that a federal gun law was passed in September 2016 preventing open carry in all 50 states. The source identifies the claim as originating from a known purveyor of fake news, Associated Media Coverage, and details why the claim is false.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes fact-check directly refutes the claim, stating it originated from a fake news site and providing evidence of its falsity.  The Snopes article highlights the absence of corroborating evidence from official sources or organizations mentioned in the fake news article.

final_result.explanation: The internal and external validation checks both strongly indicate that the original caption is out of context. The internal check notes that the image shows open carry, while the caption states a law was passed to prevent it nationwide.  This is a direct contradiction. The external check provides strong evidence from Snopes, a reputable fact-checking website, which definitively debunks the claim made in the caption. Snopes traces the false claim to a known purveyor of fake news and provides detailed explanations as to why it is false.  There is no discrepancy between the internal and external findings; both agree that the caption is false and unrelated to the image content. The high confidence score of 10 reflects the strong agreement between the internal and external validation processes and the strong evidence from a reliable source to support the determination. There is no ambiguity or uncertainty in the evidence; it clearly demonstrates the caption's inaccuracy and lack of relation to the image. The image depicts an individual openly carrying a rifle, while the caption claims a federal law banning this practice exists in all 50 states. These two statements are directly contradictory, supported by strong external evidence that debunks the caption's claim.  There is complete alignment between the image's visual content and the external fact-check's validation of the caption. The combination of the internal analysis revealing an immediate contradiction and the external verification providing strong refutation from a trustworthy source leads to a high confidence score and the conclusion that the caption is entirely out of context.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external checks strongly support the conclusion that the caption is out of context.  The internal check identifies a direct contradiction between the image and the caption's claim. The external check provides strong evidence from Snopes to debunk the caption's false assertion.
